At 18:58 29/07/2004, you wrote:
>Ian,
>
>After reading most of the article (I skimmed some), I thought it was 
>interesting.  Ultimately,
>though, from what I read he is using a purely boolean approach to his 
>activation mechanism (below
>< 2 does not fire, > 1 does fire).  Without smooth activation functions, 
>it means the evolved
>network by its nature must then create smoothness where it is needed IN 
>THE CONNECTIVITY.  That
>seems very inefficient.

This is true.

There is, however, an angle to these things when we think about 
efficiency.  When we think about the things we would like "AI" to achieve, 
we inevitably do it by comparison to ourselves.  And we achieve 
intelligence, not only via unknown techniques, but also by bringing huge 
hardware resources to the problem.

Thus, when we consider a technique and call it "inefficient" we need to 
recall that inefficiency is a relative thing, and that if computers were 
(say) 1000-fold more powerful, such inefficiency might become 
irrelevant.  In that context, some other advantage of the "inefficient" 
result might be found to achieve a result that is otherwise unattainable.

I'm not saying this is the necessarily case here (in fact I'm just being 
argumentative :) but it did occur to me while the bit-by-bit approach (as 
opposed to real-valued approaches) is less efficient in needing far-larger 
numbers of neurones to handle real values, it might be more evolvable 
because if a "behaviour" is composed of a very large number of these 1bit 
neurones, it can be very smoothly mutated -- one 1bit neurone at a time.

OTOH, he has no real-valued weights, which are another good source of 
smoothness.

>It is an interesting experiment.  I would have to see it perform over the 
>long term to be
>convinced the results were equavalent to using a smooth activation 
>functions (i.e. sigmoidal).  I
>just don't think they are.  Human distinctions in reality of 
>fuzzy.  Formal logic is just a small
>subset of human intelligence.  And very few humans use formal logic.  And 
>a pretty large number of
>these produce "valuable" solutions to problems.
